rich_text_content.text: This article describes the regulations that apply to submitting an end-of-module assessment (EMA). From a technical and functional point of view an EMA is very similar to a tutor marked assignment (TMA).

There are two ways of submitting an EMA: electronically or on paper. Some modules insist on one of these methods, others offer you the choice, so you should check your module instructions carefully to find out which applies. There you'll also find the cut-off date for the EMA as well as notes on content, layout, format etc.
You're not required to anonymise your EMA unless you've been specifically told to do so by the module team.

rich_text_content.text: Submit in good time

Please remember that electronic transmission isn't immediate. Some students experience occasional problems with their internet connection and network traffic may be particularly heavy on the cut-off date.

Students who leave electronic submission until close to midnight on the cut-off date may find that last-minute problems with their computer or internet connection can delay their submission until after midnight, making their submission subject to a penalty. If you're submitting during the penalty period and you miss the final cut-off at the end of the penalty period, your work won't be accepted for marking.
Paper submissions must arrive at the University by noon on the cut-off date and you should allow at least three working days for delivery. Be sure to obtain proof of posting.
Cut-off date and late submission
There is a grace period of 12 hours, so any examinable work received before midnight (00:00) on the cut-off date will still be accepted.

Work received late but within 24 hours of the midnight grace period will be accepted for assessment but will be subject to a mark penalty. See I’m worried I haven’t prepared enough for my exam, EMA or emTMA for more information about the penalty.
If your work is received after the 24 hour period it will not be accepted for assessment and will be returned unmarked.
For full details on submission deadlines and the late marking penalty, see section 3 of the EMA and emTMA guidelines booklet above.
EMA submission timing
Submissions received on cut-off date by 12:00 noon (UK local time) are received in time and work is accepted for marking.
Submissions received on cut-off date between 12:00 noon and 23:59 (UK local time) are within the grace period. Work is accepted for marking and no penalty incurred.
Submissions received on day 1 after cut-off date between 00:00 and 23:59 (UK local time). Work is accepted for marking however a penalty is incurred.
Submissions received on day 2 after cut-off date from 00:00 onwards (UK local time) are not marked.
Sources of help
If you experience difficulties, you should refer to the information in the EMA and emTMA guidelines booklet.  If you still need assistance, please refer to the contacts below.

Policy information: email assignments@open.ac.uk
Telephone: +44 (0)1908 655291, Monday to Friday 09:00-17:00
Technical help: contact the Computing Helpdesk

rich_text_content.text: We hope you're pleased with your results. Getting a pass is a significant milestone and means you can continue to progress with your studies.

To find out how your module has been assessed, find the assessment strategy on StudentHome. In the centre panel, under the title of the module you're enrolled on, select ‘Assessment’ (or ‘Assessment scores’), then select ‘Assessment strategy’.
You can also watch this short video on how modules are assessed.

video_transcript.text: Meet Andy. Like you, he's a student.
Andy doesn't know how his module is assessed.
There are two main ways that we assess your work.
One way...
You'll need to complete a number of assessment tasks such as assignments, dissertations, exams, speaking assessments, portfolios, practical assessments and projects.
There might only be one type of task for your module or you could have more than one type of task, for example, assignments and exams.
The marks for these tasks are put into a pot and are used to calculate your overall module result.
Another way we may assess your module is by using OCAS (Overall Continuous Assessment Score) and OES (Overall Examinable Score).
Assignment + assignment + assignment = OCAS.
An exam + an End of Module Assessment (EMA), for example, dissertation, portfolio or project = OES.
The marks for these tasks are put into a pot and are used to calculate your overall module result.
Check the assessment strategy for your module in StudentHome.

rich_text_content.text: If you're OK with your result, you can now progress on to your next module(s). Enrolment on modules for the new academic year opens in March and closes three weeks before the start of the module. For example, for modules starting in:
October, you can enrol from March to September
February, you can enrol from March to January.
If you're ready to enrol and registration is open click the button below.
If you're not happy with your result

If you're feeling disappointed with your results, take a moment to think about what is making you feel that way. Even if your score is lower than your previous results, or that of other students, it's important to consider factors that may have affected your performance, for example your personal circumstances or a particular assignment you found difficult.

You can’t retake a module to try to achieve a higher result. Nor can you appeal your result solely because you feel it should have been higher. The academic judgement of the Module Results Panel (MRP) is final. Careful checks are made at every stage of the award process to make sure that the MRP’s decisions rest on full and accurate information. Mistakes are therefore very rare.
If you have strong evidence that your module result may be wrong, you can ask for a module result check.
Where are you in your studies?

While you might feel disappointed by your result, it’s important to consider the bigger picture. It may not have as large an impact on your studies as you might think. A disappointing result is often a minor setback rather than a complete disaster for your study goals.

If you’ve recently started your studies and your module(s) is at Stage 1 undergraduate, you don’t need to worry about your grade if you’ve passed. Stage 1 grades don't count towards your final degree classification. A low result at Stage 1 won't prevent you achieving a good classification, but you may want to think about how you can learn from this experience and achieve the result you want on your next module(s).

Even if you're further on in your studies, one bad result is not necessarily disastrous. Although your Stage 2 module grades do contribute towards your classification, they are single-weighted, whereas your Stage 3 module grades are double-weighted. This means a lower result at Stage 2 could be balanced out by higher results at Stage 3.
If you're nearing the end of your studies and want to work out your likely classification, see our information about understanding your qualification classification.
Reflect on your study skills and habits

As you start to look forward towards your next module(s) it’s worth taking some time to think about reasons why you might not have done as well as you hoped and the actions you can take now to help you learn from the experience and do better next time.

If you’ve been studying more than one module at the same time, remember you can reduce this and study just one module. You'll take a little longer to complete your qualification but concentrating your time on a single module may allow you to achieve higher results.

Consider your circumstances and how you find time to study. Specific circumstances may have had an impact on your time or capacity to study. You may, for example, have had additional demands on your time such as work or childcare and you might want to consider whether these are likely to continue and how you’ll manage study if they're ongoing.
One way to get ahead and think about how and when you'll study is to use our time planning tool.  If you tend to find yourself pushed for time, time management skills may also be useful.
Resources to improve study skills
We have a range of free resources to help you improve and develop your skills. Here are some you might want to try:

fields.link_list_description: Learn how to interpret questions and how to plan, structure and write an assignment or report (15 hours of study).

fields.link_list_title: All my own work: exploring academic integrity
fields.link_list_description: How to turn what you're reading into 'your own words' (6 hours of study).

Many students struggle with referencing and ensuring they avoid plagiarism when they move up to Stage 2 and 3. If you’ve lost marks for this or are about to move up a stage this will be useful (5 hours of study).
Discover the skills required for online study and evaluate your own study skillset (6 hours of study).
A course to help you develop your awareness of just how much you have already learned and what you are capable of (24 hours of study).

rich_text_content.text: You should also look at your Study website (click on ‘Study’ in the navigation bar at the top of the page) where you'll find subject-specific resources and suggestions about how you can prepare for certain modules and for moving to the next level in your studies.
Reflect on tutor feedback

It’s really important to read the feedback tutors give you on each of your TMAs. While it can be difficult to read critical feedback, it’s the best way to learn from your mistakes and ensure you don’t repeat them.

Looking back at your TMA feedback, has your tutor suggested anything you can improve on? Are there any recurring themes? If, for example, you have received feedback saying your work is not well structured then you might benefit from working on your essay writing skills. Some of the feedback may be specific to the module, but there will be general comments that will be useful for your next module.

Write down some notes about where you feel you need to improve. Your tutor(s) will email you just before your next module(s) starts, your tutor(s) will email you. You can then reply to this email outlining the areas where you would like help to improve during your next module. Do not be afraid of doing this, tutors will appreciate you wanting to develop your skills and will work with you to do this.
Help with career planning
Even if your results mean that you might now get a lower degree classification than you hoped, it doesn’t have to impact your career goals.

Whether you’re already planning and know what your career aims are, or if you’re not sure where to begin, online self-assessment tools are where you should start. Identify which roles match your skills, experience and interests helps you know whether the job you want is right for you and what careers complement who you are when planning for your future.  Kudos AD is a really good tool to try. You may also like to have a look at our resources on Reviewing careers options after module results.

rich_text_content.text: To receive your qualification you need to ensure that you've passed all the required modules and they're all linked to the qualification. You can check this on your study record.

Note the older version of the Open degree (qualification code BD) was withdrawn at the end of December 2019. If you’re on this qualification to complete your final 60 credits for the Honours degree and have any concerns about completing it, you should contact your student support team to discuss your options.
Accepting your qualification

You'll receive an email telling you that you're eligible for your qualification. You can expect to receive your qualification offer, or confirmation that you've qualified for it, on your qualification record on StudentHome within three working days of your final module result being released. To accept your qualification offer, log on to StudentHome and follow the links.

If you have been granted an exceptional permission to link in any alternative module credit, there will be additional processing time before you receive notification of your qualification. This could take between 3 and 20 working days, depending on the complexity and volumes being handled. If you have any queries you can contact acc-gen@open.ac.uk.
Your offer will provide details of the classification you’ve received. Find out more about understanding your qualification classification.
This will also give you instructions on the action you need to take to accept your qualification and book your degree ceremony (if eligible).

Please remember to check that your name is correct for the certificate. If you want us to make any amendments to your name - including adding special characters or accents - you'll need to reply within 7 days, using the link in the email or to ss-correction-of-name@open.ac.uk.
Receiving your certificate

Providing you've accepted your qualification you'll be able to download a Diploma Supplement from your study record. This can be used as official confirmation of your qualification prior to receiving your certificate.

We produce your certificate on watermarked stationery, with the University crest and hologram, and the OU seal. It's sent out by post to the address we hold for you on our records. Please make sure your address details are up to date. You should expect to receive your certificate within 6 to 8 weeks from the date of acceptance.

node.title: Understanding your qualification classification
node.description: How we work out what degree classification you receive, plus the rules about what study you can count towards your qualification.

primary.introduction_text: Undergraduate bachelors degrees with honours, including Scottish 480 credit undergraduate bachelors degrees, and integrated masters degrees are awarded with a classification of honours. No other undergraduate qualifications are classified. The Open University awards the same four classes of honours degrees as other UK universities: first-class (1), upper second-class (2.1), lower second-class (2.2) and third-class (3).

rich_text_content.text: Postgraduate qualifications are classified as distinction, merit or pass. The regulations for the classification of postgraduate qualifications are in the Academic Regulations and in the regulations for each individual qualification.
Understanding your honours degree classification
The classification process only takes place when all the requirements of your degree have been met. This includes checks to ensure you have
sufficient credit, including any recognition of prior learning or credit transfer
the right credit for the degree, including compulsory modules where applicable
credit completed within the time limit for your qualification
the unique study required for your qualification.
The regulations for the classification of honours degree are in the Academic Regulations.

There are also two separate guidance documents which provide worked examples of classification for bachelors degrees (both 360-credit bachelors degrees and 480-credit Scottish bachelors degrees) and integrated masters degrees. They also include examples of how classification is calculated for the different types of honours degrees and in different situations, which can include one or more of the following factors:
an award of recognition for prior learning (RPL) or credit transfer
degrees which include exceptional stage credit
counted-down credit or other exceptional permissions
more credit than required.
These documents can be found in Understanding your class of honours.
Example of how a bachelors degree classification is calculated

Your degree classification will be awarded using a weighted grade credit score calculated from your module results from 120 credits at Level 2 and 120 credits at Level 3. Your Level 1 module grades are not included.

If you've completed 360 credits of new OU study for a 360-credit bachelors degree, an outline explanation of how your classification is calculated is in the following example. The steps and example are for illustrative purposes and only apply to undergraduate bachelors honours 360 credit degrees awarded after 1 March 2023.

code.text:
1. List module grades

    Look at the grades received for level 2 and level 3 modules which are linked to the degree - 120 credits at each level.

  2. Calculate the Level 2 score

    Level 2 grades are single weighted. Multiply the credits of each level 2 module by their grades (1,2,3 or 4) and add together. For example (60 credits × grade 1 = 60) + (60 credits × grade 2 = 120) total 180.

  3. Calculate the Level 3 score

    Level 3 results are double weighted. Multiply the credits of each level 3 module by their grades (1,2,3 or 4), and add together. Multiple the result by two. For example (60 credits × grade 1 = 60) + (60 credits × grade 3 = 180) = 240 × 2, total 480.

  4. Calculate the weighted grade credit score

    Add the level 2 and level 3 scores together. In this example 180 + 480 = 660

  5. Check the classification table

    Check on the undergraduate honours classification table (table 1 below) to see where the score fits. If the score is within the classification band, this gives the degree classification. If the score is also within the borderline range, move to step 6. For example, the 660 score in step 4 fits within the 631 - 690 borderline range.

  6. Borderline test

    Check the module results for level 3. If there are at least 60 credits that meet the borderline test, then the higher degree class is awarded. For this example, 660 is in the borderline range for first-class. If there are 60 level 3 credits at grade 1, then first-class is awarded.

node.title: Preparing for your exam
node.description: Tips and techniques for revising for your exams and using the exam time effectively
node.keywords: exam preparation, exam tips, exam techniques, exam tips and techniques, past exam papers, exam specimen papers, specimen papers, past papers, revision, revision techniques, revising, timings, timing, remote exam, online exam, computer exam,

primary.introduction_text: As well as the revision you'll have been doing, the lead up to an exam can be a stressful time. There are some key practical things you should think about ahead of your exam.

rich_text_content.text: Think about
where you’ll work to have as much peace and quiet as possible
checking you’ll have access to a computer and reliable broadband
planning ahead – make sure you know the date and time of your exam, how you'll access it and how to submit
how you’ll organise and manage the timings; do you concentrate best in the mornings, afternoons or evenings?
deciding a 'cut off' time so that you don’t have to rush the process of submitting your final answers.

When thinking about where might be a suitable place to take your exam, we’d recommend you find a space that is warm and well-ventilated, with a desk that allows space for you to use your equipment comfortably.

Make sure you familiarise yourself with all the information on your module website about your exam. Attend any exam preparation tutorials that are available (remember you can also watch recordings of these if you need to revisit them or can’t attend a live session. See Find and view recorded tutorials for information on where to find the recordings). Try out a specimen exam paper from your module website to help you know what to expect and how your exam will be structured.

You can also join interactive exam preparation events on StudentHub Live or watch them on catch-up after the live event. These will not be specific to your module but will help you with general preparation and exam techniques. Find out more about StudentHub Live events.

To get the most out of your revision time start early. Don’t leave it to the last minute. Make sure you have a good schedule and prepare well. Look back over the content in your module. You'll be able to access the internet and your module materials during your exam, but it’s important that you still revise as you may not have time in the exam to find answers to the questions.

In the following video Cath Brown, former OU Students' Association President, shares her tips and techniques to help you get ready for your exam. This video does talk about exams taken at an exam centre, but it still has lots of useful tips in it.

fields.video_title: Tips and techniques to get ready for exams

video_transcript.text: Cath Brown (Former OU Students' Association President): So, we’re coming up to the time of the year when everyone’s thinking about exams! Sorry to use a swear-word, not nice is it. But I’m here to try and give a little bit of constructive help, erm, speaking as an OU student who has done shed loads of the things over the years.

The first thing to say is DON’T PANIC! You’re not doomed, you’re really not, even if you feel you’re not good at exams, you can do things about it to help you get better. And the first thing to say is remember, they will try and mark you more easily in exams than they do in TMAs, they’re looking to give you marks, they’re not looking to take them away. So, don’t think that they’re out to get you because they’re really not.

Now let’s think about that actual revision. So first thing you need to ask yourself is what do I actually need to know? So be aware, what are the learning objectives, have a look at the summaries from your module, look at any information they’ve given you about preparing for the exam because most of them will actually do that. In some subjects they may actually give you information in the exam, like if you’re doing STEM subjects you may often have a handbook, or a data sheet or something like that, so check what’s on that because if it’s already in there, you don’t need to learn it do you!

So that’s a really important thing to check, and don’t forget, have a look at the specimen paper, there’ll be one of those on your module website, and for a lot of subjects there’ll be past papers, and you can get those in the OU Students’ shop, don’t get too distracted by all the nice goodies in there and spend too much money as procrastination but er, you know, do go in there, get the exam papers and maybe buy a teddy just on the side.

So, let’s think about actually planning what you’re doing. Now, if you look at what you’ve studied, it’s probably going to be in four categories, there’s going to be stuff that I’m going to call ‘type A’ which is stuff that you know you can do, you don’t really need to worry about it. Now, a lot of people spend too much time revising ‘type A’ stuff, because it’s comforting, it’s nice, it’s a comfort blanket, no, don’t do that, if you already know it then you don’t need to learn it. Then there’s ‘type B’ stuff, and type b is things where you understood it at the time but maybe you don’t remember it so well. You need to revise this folks because, if you didn’t remember it at the time you need to remember it for the exam. Then there’s ‘type C’ and type C is when it starts getting a little bit uncomfortable, and that’s things that maybe you didn’t get so well but you know it’s really really important, maybe your tutor has reminded you it’s important, maybe you’ve seen it comes up in past exam questions, now type C you really need to focus on, and get it in early because if you’re still stuck on it you need time to ask your tutor and talk to your fellow students about it. And then there’s type D, type D is these horrible little niggly bits that always you can’t quite get your head round, but, they don’t come up that much, maybe they’ve come up once in five years, forget type D, these stupid little niggles, they’re not that important, don’t worry about them.

So, onto the stuff that you didn’t quite get that was important first, then onto the stuff that you did get but you don’t remember, they’re your two main types of things to focus on when you’re revising. Now let’s think about how you revise, now there are many bits of advice about how to revise as there are people, but there are few key things that proper actual serious academic research, you know, the sort of thing you’d have to give a reference for, actually shows applies for everybody. And the first one is, if you want to remember stuff, you actually get better at remembering by trying to remember – who knew? It’s like practicing everything else. So, you need to, during your revision, try remembering things, test yourself. The second one is, it doesn’t work to learn all of something all at once, and then never come back to it again. What you need to do is to keep revisiting it, so, do a little bit of your first topic then onto your second topic and then on to your third topic and then maybe next week, come back to the first topic again. You can’t just do it all and then not do anything before the exam because it just won’t stay in your brain. And the third one is being active, hardly anyone can revise by just actually sitting there and reading because you start staring through the pages don’t you, you know you start thinking what your dinner is, what holiday you’re going to book, how cute your cat looks or your dog if you’re a dog person, erm, you don’t concentrate so you need to be active. Now let’s think about what you could do to be active. Well, a lot of people find making their own summaries is good, now if you’re me, I’m not one of these creative people, I just do bullet points, but lots of people do nice things like mind maps, so give it a go, see which of those works. Quite a few people find actually that if they record themselves and listen to themselves that helps, and also explaining it to someone else, if you haven’t actually got family members who’ll agree, explain it to your cat or the dog, they won’t usually object, and think how much those study buddies have helped you during the year, I’m sure they’d love to help you with your revision as well. So, make sure you’re doing those sorts of things.

Now, if you’re going to plan your revision you’ve got to be realistic, don’t say you’re going to do 10 hours a day on it because believe me, you’re not. If anything, under estimate, then you’ve got a little bit of leeway haven’t you. And also, make sure you take some breaks, not enough breaks that you can then go and play a family game of Monopoly, or you’re going to go for a 10 mile hike, but enough time to maybe just go down the corner shop, make yourself a cup of tea, those sorts of things, and take a break when your brain is switching off, if you’re staring at the page and you’re thinking “I’ve no idea what this is about”, take a break. And variety, who on Earth can actually do the same thing for that long and stay focussed? So, think about doing things like preparing those summaries, testing yourself, doing past paper questions, revisiting TMAs, maybe listening to tutorial recordings, there’s all sorts of different things you can do, build in that variety to stop yourself just switching off.

Now let’s think about past papers because they’re really really important. And one of the reasons they’re important is because actually taking the exam is a skill in itself. You wouldn’t go into your driving test and think “Oh well, I’ll just go into my driving test and I won’t practice the manoeuvres”, same way, you don’t go into an exam without practicing actually doing the taking the exam. So to do that, you need to get your past paper, you need to sit yourself down in proper exam conditions, no sneaky peeks at the book, no sneaky wanders out to the shop or playing games or anything like that, three hours, sat there, no books, at your table, write your answers out in full, don’t just think “Oh I know that bit I won’t write the rest of it”, write it all, otherwise your timing’s just going to go a bit wonky isn’t it. So, do those practice papers. Me, I’d always do at least three at a time, you may not feel you’ve got that much time but that’s what I do. When you’ve done them, go back to them, this time with your notes, and see, OK, did I get everything in I should do? Are there things you keep forgetting? If there’s stuff you keep forgetting, make a note of it so you can adjust your revision accordingly.

And then let’s actually think about preparing for that dreaded day when you’ve actually got to turn up to the exam centre. Now, your exam’s going to be in a morning or an afternoon, now, I know that’s a bummer if you’re not an afternoon person or you’re not a morning person, but it does help, if you know your exam’s in the afternoon, get in the habit of doing a bit of academic work in the afternoon. There’s no point trying to convince your body that it wants to do an exam in the afternoon if you’re used to just having a bit of a snooze then is there? So get in that habit and keep yourself fresh. Once when I was a very young and silly 20 year old, I turned up to an exam having done lots of last-minute ‘cramming’ and I was fuelled up with glucose tablets and Pro-plus, nothing illegal note, it was all perfectly legal but I was fuelled up with that, and I was so jittery, I could not think straight, and guess what, that’s the one exam in my life I really made a mess of. So make sure you’re fresh, make sure your sleep cycle ties in with the exam. And I’m going to finish off again by saying what I said at the beginning, don’t panic, they want you to do well, they want to give you the marks. And finally, if something does go wrong, maybe things were a bit difficult coming up with health-wise, or family matters up to the exam, don’t forget you can fill in special circs, that can make a difference.
Now get revising everyone, and the best of luck!

rich_text_content.text: It’s good to have a plan on how you'll work through the exam. The following techniques will help with this:
read the instructions carefully
plan your time - for example, what questions you'll answer, how much time you'll spend on each answer, and in which order you'll answer the questions
start with the question you're most confident with
if you get stuck - move on, you can always come back to the question
check your answers when you've finished.

It may be helpful to switch on any answering machine and put a sign on the door to avoid disturbances. If necessary, ask someone to look after your children or pets so you can give your full attention to your exam. rich_text_content.text: What are special circumstances?

Special circumstances are things of a serious nature which you feel affected your performance in any of the assessed tasks. They can only be considered in exceptional cases, so please think carefully whether your case merits attention before completing the form. The kinds of special circumstance we may make allowance for include:
serious and prolonged illness
bereavement
the loss of more than 10 minutes of exam time, due to circumstances beyond your control
serious disruption of studies caused by the University
inadequate adjustments made by the University for any disability or additional requirement you’ve told us about.

The information you give us about your special circumstances will only be used to your benefit. It will be made available to the Module Result Panel for them to consider when they meet to agree your final result. However the Panel can only give limited weight to any information you provide and don't consider events that could have been anticipated.

There are some circumstances that are unlikely to be considered as special circumstances, for example normal commitments or constraints from paid employment, over-sleeping, holidays, English being an additional language, moving house, deadlines for module tasks being set close together, financial difficulties, attending or taking part in sporting or social events and voluntary work.
How to submit special circumstances
Complete and submit the online form using the button below.
You must submit a separate form for each module where you feel your circumstances affected your performance.

We must receive the form(s) before midnight (00.00), UK local time, four calendar days after the exam/speaking test or submission cut-off date for your final piece of assessed work. Please note, this deadline of four calendar days from the submission cut-off date does not include any late penalty period.

If you want to submit any written third-party evidence supporting what adversely affected your performance, you can attach it electronically on the webform. If you email or post it to us, we must receive it within 14 days of your submission. We don’t need you to send the original documents - copies are fine.
What evidence can I submit?

Your evidence should include enough detail about your circumstances that we can verify the impact you’ve described. In particular, it should confirm the dates when your circumstances occurred and ideally what impact those circumstances had on you.

You are usually expected to submit evidence in order for your special circumstances to be considered. If you're struggling to find evidence or can't provide any to support your submission please provide as much detail as possible, including the impact this has had on your studies. The Module Result Panel may still be able to take your circumstances into account.

For example, if you’ve been caring for a sick relative, but don’t have any evidence from your own doctor – please send us evidence to confirm the circumstances and when they occurred. You’ll need to use the special circumstances form to explain to us in more detail how this affected you.
All written documentation must be in English or have a translation included. The types of evidence that we expect to receive for different circumstances are detailed below.

Exceptional personal circumstances (for example, the illness of a dependent or repossession of your accommodation): A letter from a counsellor/GP or a relevant independent third-party explaining, in their professional opinion:
The severity of the circumstances
The dates when your circumstances occurred
The impact the circumstances had on you personally
How this may have affected your ability to engage with your academic work.
Serious illness or injury: A medical certificate or letter from your GP or other medical specialist involved in your care explaining, in their professional opinion:
The severity of the circumstances
The dates when your circumstances occurred
The impact the circumstances had on you personally
How this may have affected your ability to engage with your academic work

A close bereavement: A death certificate, obituary notice or funeral order of service. Additional evidence (i.e. statement from a counsellor regarding grief counselling in progress) should be provided where difficulties are experienced for an extended period.
Victim of a serious crime: A crime reference number, legal documents.

Disabilities for which reasonable adjustments weren’t in place as agreed or weren’t sufficient: A Disabled Students Allowances (DSA) report showing recommendations that weren’t followed, or copies of communications between you and the University where you’ve discussed adjustments.

Serious and unforeseeable transport difficulties: A letter from the relevant transport company or evidence of a major road incident (such as a screenshot of a local news report clearly showing the date and location).
Submit special circumstances
You can use this form to submit special circumstances for any type of assessment on your module.
If you're having technical problems submitting this form please contact your SST.
Missed the deadline?

Information about special circumstances that arrives late won’t be considered unless you can show you couldn’t meet the deadline because of circumstances outside your control. This would have to be something serious like being in hospital.

rich_text_content.text: If you're thinking about working in another country, there are a few things that are useful to consider.
The type of work, will it be temporary or more permanent?
What you want out of it, to progress in your career or to gain experience of living and working abroad?

Finding out if you need to get your Open University (OU) qualification recognised and how to go about doing it.
A good place to start your research is the Prospects website which has a range of information about working abroad by country.
The OU cannot advise you on how Brexit may affect your status or career plans. However, as the United Kingdom has left the European Union, you could be affected if:
you're an OU student or graduate with British nationality considering career opportunities within the EU
you're an OU student or graduate and citizen of an EU country but currently resident or planning to reside in the UK.
The UK government provides information about current policy and changes under Brexit guidance.
International recognition of your OU qualification

Many employers outside the UK will recognise UK qualifications and many understand that an OU degree is equal in academic standard to a degree from any other UK university. Smaller employers may be less familiar with the OU, and you might need to provide additional explanatory information. If you intend to use your qualifications to seek work or do further study abroad, then check whether your intended qualification will meet local requirements for your chosen career, and ideally before you enrol on any course.

You can apply for official recognition of your degree, but it’s a complex process as each country has its own legal and administrative framework, so check with prospective employers and only seek this if it’s necessary.
For more information about how you can use your OU qualification abroad when looking for work or further study see the OU's guide to recognition of qualifications outside the UK.
Needing professional body membership or status

You may also need professional body membership or professional status, in addition to your degree for example in Chartered Engineer jobs. If this is the case, you'll need to find out if your chosen degree will allow entry to the next qualifying stage. This could include additional professional examinations and/or a period of accredited work experience.
Secondments, work experience and internships

Larger international employers may offer secondments (if already working for the employer) or transfers abroad so it may be worth researching companies to see what opportunities they have and where their head offices are based.

If you're looking at work experience or internships, there may be specific schemes available or companies that will manage placements, although always consider what costs may be involved. The Prospects working abroad pages have information on summer jobs and internships.
Networking

Networking can be important; try using LinkedIn as a tool to research what opportunities there may be and potential contacts and groups. Specialist recruitment agencies in the country could also be useful in helping you identify opportunities.

primary.introduction_text: You need to tell us about any relevant unspent criminal convictions so we can support you in complying with any conditions or restrictions you have. We also need to balance our obligations towards applicants with criminal convictions with the safety and welfare of the wider student and staff community, and those visiting the University or attending events.

rich_text_content.text: By agreeing to our Conditions of Registration, you formally confirm that you’ll tell us of any current legal restriction, condition or arrangement. This includes disclosure if you’re on the Sexual Offender Register or have a Sexual Harm Prevention Order.
Assessing how we can support you can take up to 10 weeks, depending on how quickly we receive information from your probation or reporting officer.
The criminal convictions you need to tell us about
Relevant unspent convictions include:
Offences listed in the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (in the United Kingdom or equivalent Act for outside of the United Kingdom).
Any kind of violence including (but not limited to) threatening behaviour, offences concerning the intention to harm, or offences which resulted in actual bodily harm.
Offences listed in the Terrorism Act 2006 (in the United Kingdom or equivalent Act for outside of the United Kingdom).
The unlawful supply of controlled drugs or substances where the conviction concerns commercial drug dealing or trafficking.
Offences involving firearms, weapons, crossbows and knives.
Offences involving arson.
Fraud.
Offences of human trafficking, slavery and forced labour.
You don’t need to tell us about fixed penalty offences such as minor motoring offences.
If you're unsure whether a conviction is spent or not, and therefore whether you need to disclose it, you can check using the conviction caution tool on gov.uk
We also consider relevant convictions for students under 18 considered a child under English law.
How to tell us about your criminal convictions

You’ll be asked to disclose any unspent criminal convictions as part of the registration process. Or you can tell us at any point during your studies if you receive a conviction after your module has started.

If you tell us during the registration process, you'll be contacted by a member of our specialist advice team who supports students in prison, secure hospitals and those with legal restrictions, conditions or arrangements related to criminal convictions. Our Students in Secure Environments (SiSE) team will provide guidance and support to help you get the most out of your study. Your conversations with them are confidential

You’ll be asked for more information including permission to contact your probation or reporting officer. This information will be used to assess if access to some activities should be restricted and suggest alternative modules if your first choice is impractical due to your conditions or restrictions.
To tell us about a conviction once you’ve started studying, contact our specialist advice team who’ll support you through the process.
Incorrectly ticked 'yes' to disclosing a criminal conviction when registering

If you ticked 'yes' to the question asking if you have an unspent criminal conviction as you went through the registration process but you didn't mean to, you'll receive an email asking you to complete and return a form.  On that form, you can formally tell us that you do not have anything to disclose.  We'll then correct your record.  If you do this within seven days, your registration will continue uninterrupted.  We're not able take this information over the phone as we need written confirmation from you.  Please remember that failing to disclose an unspent criminal conviction may lead to disciplinary action.

Assessment

Assessment is the term we use to mean all the ways the University assesses how you're progressing during your module. It covers things like TMAs, iCMAs, exams, emTMAs and EMAs.

Assessment banking

If you've arranged a deferral and your module is eligible, it may be possible for you to keep the scores from assessments you've already completed and carry these forward to a future presentation of the same module. You won't be able to go back and submit any assignments you missed out. Bear in mind assessment banking isn't available on all modules, and must be discussed with your student support team first, to explore if it's a good option for you.

Assessment strategy

A detailed breakdown of the way a module is assessed (such as the learning outcomes to be met, type and number of assessments and their weighting). Information about this can be found on your module record on StudentHome. There may also be information in the module guide, assignment booklets or module materials.

Assignments

Assignments is the term we use for the parts of the module assessment that aren't the final assessed task - for example, TMAs, iCMAs and reports.

Back to top

Capped

Resits and resubmissions are normally capped at the lowest grade of pass. This means your module result following a resit or resubmission won't be higher than a bare Pass or Pass 4 grade.

Cluster Examination and Assessment Board (Cluster EAB)

The Cluster EAB will confirm the standards of the module result process and recommend a result for each student in the cluster within a conflation period. Cluster EABs will include one or more External Examiner.

Component of assessment

This term refers to means your overall continuous assessment score (OCAS), your overall examinable component score (OES) or your overall assessment score (OAS). More generally, it's a set of assessed tasks on which the Module Result Panel sets overall thresholds for each grade of pass when determining module results.

Continuous assessment

The name given to the set of assignments (TMAs and iCMAs) that you complete during a module. Information about these can be found in the module guide, assignment booklets or module materials. See also summative assessment and formative assessment.

Back to top

Deferral

Stopping a module part way through with the aim of returning to finish it later. See also assessment banking.

Discretionary postponement

If you can't complete your exam, EMA or emTMA, the University may give you permission to postpone it to the next available opportunity. You'll need to provide third party evidence of serious and unexpected circumstances outside your control, which prevent you from sitting your exam or submitting your work at the scheduled time. Strict criteria and deadlines apply.

Back to top

Elective postponement

If you're offered a resit or resubmission within 12-16 weeks of your original exam or EMA/emTMA submission, you may be able to postpone the resit/resubmission to the next available opportunity. You should note this could be up to 9 months later.

End-of-module assessment (EMA)

On many modules, you have to work independently to produce an extended piece of work rather than sitting a traditional exam at the end of your study. For ease of reference, these essays, projects, portfolios, dissertations, assessments, etc. are referred to collectively as end-of-module assessments (EMAs). EMAs can take many forms, ranging from a very short piece of text written in a foreign language, through project reports of a few thousand words in length, to files of evidence summarising your achievements during the module, up to a 50,000-word dissertation. A word limit and a strictly-policed submission deadline apply to EMAs, so you need to develop skills in time and content management.

On the majority of modules, EMAs have to be submitted electronically.

Extensions aren't allowed for EMAs under any circumstances.

Very occasionally, a module may have both an EMA and an exam.

More information can be found in the EMA and emTMA guidelines booklet (PDF, 228 KB).

End-of-module tutor-marked assignment (emTMA)

The final TMA on modules with no exam or EMA.

Equally weighted

Module assessment strategies with two components, such as Overall Examinable Score (OES) and Overall Continuous Assessment Score (OCAS), often refer to the two components as being equally weighted. This means they have the same value when the rank score is calculated in the module. However, you must reach the thresholds on the OES, the OCAS and rank separately to pass the module or achieve each grade of pass, irrespective of the weighting.

ET3

The cover sheet that accompanies each copy of the end-of-module assessment (EMA) if you have to submit your work on paper.

eTMA/eEMA system

The University's system that allows you to submit work electronically for assessment.

Examinable component

The name given to one or more tasks on modules with two components of assessment. It's usually undertaken at the end of a module and is marked by someone other than your tutor. For most modules with an examinable component, this is made up of an exam or end-of-module assessment (EMA), but it can include other items of examinable work. More information can be found in the module materials. Very occasionally a module may have both an exam and an EMA.

Exams

The University holds a number of different types of exam in exam periods at the end of module presentations. Exams will be online and taken remotely. The duration and format of exams varies by module.

External Examiner

External Examiners form an important part of the University's quality assurance processes. They ensure results are determined fairly and advise the University on comparability with other Higher Education institutions.

Back to top

Fail

The required standard hasn't been achieved for a pass result to be awarded. The Module Results Determination Policy contains more information about module result statuses.

Formative assignment

In contrast to a summative assignment, a formative assignment doesn't normally count towards the overall module result. It's used on some modules for teaching purposes only but it's important to note it could still be compulsory and you might not pass a module if you don't submit it. Check your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome) to find out more.

Back to top

Interactive computer-marked assignment (iCMA)

An interactive computer-marked assignment submitted online which can incorporate short answers or drag and drop answers as well as the traditional multiple choice questions. Some iCMAs give more than one chance at a question, and some offer immediate feedback on the answer.

Back to top

Module Result Panel (MRP)

The Module Result Panel (MRP) is responsible for the setting and marking of all controlled assessments for each presentation of a specific module, and for proposing a result for each student on a module presentation to the Cluster Examination and Assessment Board (Cluster EAB).

Back to top

Overall assessment score (OAS)

All the assessment for your module will be in either Overall Continuous Assessment Score (OCAS) or Overall Examinable Score (OES). There will only be one component and your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome) will explain what you must do to pass the module.

Overall continuous assessment score (OCAS)

This is a score out of 100 which has been achieved for continuous assessment on the module. Continuous assessment is usually made up of assignments such as tutor marked assignments (TMAs) and interactive computer marked assessments (iCMAs). Your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome) will explain how much each individual assignment contributes towards OCAS.

Overall examinable component score (OES)

This is a score out of 100 which has been achieved for the examinable component on modules with two separate components of assessment. The examinable component is usually an exam or an end-of-module assessment (EMA) such as a project, poster, speaking assessment (language modules) or dissertation. It may also be a combination of these types of assessment. Very occasionally, a module may have both an EMA and an exam.

Back to top

Pass

The required standard has been achieved by the student. The Module Results Determination Policy contains more information about module result statuses.

Poster presentation

Poster presentations are used mainly on science modules. You'll need to produce a poster that conveys your understanding of a particular topic. The poster format imposes strict restrictions on page size and word count. It therefore requires you to demonstrate your skills in summarising and presenting information. This allows 'communication skills' features such as layout and appropriate use of text and pictorial information to be assessed at the same time as the academic content of your poster.

PT3

The form used by your tutor to record their marks and comments for a TMA or emTMA. For modules where you submit your TMA on paper, this form is used as a cover sheet. A blank form is enclosed with the module materials and a new form will be sent to you with each returned TMA. You'll get a copy of the completed PT3 for each marked TMA. For eTMAs, the system automatically generates an electronic PT3 when each TMA is returned to you. Note the PT3 for an emTMA isn't available until your module result is released.

Back to top

Rank score

For modules with more than one component of assessment, the rank score is the weighted average of the Overall Examinable Score (OES) and Overall Continuous Assessment Score (OCAS) components.

Resit

If you take your exam but don't achieve the required standard for a pass on your module, you may be offered a resit opportunity. There is a minimum requirement to qualify for a resit specific to your module/s, which is explained in the Assessment section on StudentHome. You can only resit once and your module result will normally be capped.

Resubmission

If you submit your end-of-module assessment (EMA) or end-of-module tutor-marked assignment (emTMA) but don't achieve the required standard for a pass on your module, you may be offered a resubmission opportunity. There is a minimum requirement to qualify for a resubmission specific to your module/s, which is explained in the Assessment section on StudentHome. You may only resubmit once, and your module result will normally be capped.

Back to top

Speaking assessments

Speaking assessments are normally used on language modules to assess your speaking and listening skills.

Special circumstances

If your performance in any of the assessment on your module has been affected by something beyond your control, you can bring these 'special circumstances' to the attention of the Module Result Panel for consideration when they agree your module result. Please see Special Circumstances - exams, EMAs or emTMAs for details of the criteria and deadlines that apply.

Substitution score

If a module permits substitution, it's applied at the end of the module but only if it will improve your OCAS score. Substitution is explained in What is substitution?.

Summative assignment

An assignment that counts towards the overall module result. See also formative assignment.

Back to top

Threshold

On some modules there's a minimum requirement or score (such as 40%) that you must achieve for an individual piece of work or activity, or for a number of pieces of work combined, in order to achieve a pass result. Information about this can be found in your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome).

Tutor-marked assignment (TMA)

As part of the teaching methodology on most modules, you have to submit written assignments to your tutor. These are called tutor-marked assignments. For most modules you have to submit your assignments electronically using the University's online eTMA (electronic tutor-marked assignment) system. Tutors access the assignment, mark it online and upload it back to the system. The system records the score and automatically makes the marked assignment available to you. Some modules can't use eTMAs due to the type of work, so they're submitted on paper. In these cases your tutor marks the assignment, giving a score and written comments on the PT3 form, and sends it to the University by post for the score to be recorded. The assignment and a copy of the PT3 form are then returned to you by post. See also PT3 and emTMA.

Back to top

Viva voce

Where a Module Result Panel (MRP) decides it would like to obtain more evidence before agreeing your module result, it may offer you a viva voce assessment. The MRP decides on the format of that assessment - it may be written, spoken or both. We'll tell you that you're being offered a viva voce at or before the module result release date. A separate communication will be sent about the format of the viva voce and when it will be held. The module result is held pending the outcome of the viva voce.

Viva voce assessments aren't available to students on request.

Back to top

Weighted average

For modules with only one component of assessment, not all tasks are equally weighted when determining module results. Overall scores are determined by a weighted average. This is the calculation of a student’s overall assessment score (OAS) from an average resulting from the multiplication of each score by its weighting. Your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome) will tell you the weighting for each assessed task.

Back to top

node.title: Resitting exams and resubmitting EMAs or emTMAs
node.description: What to do if you fail your exam or EMA and want to take a resit or resubmit.
node.keywords: End of Module Assessment, exam, examination, examinable component, fail, resit, resubmit, resitting, resubmitting, capped, cap, pass, grade, pass grade, postpone, postponement

related_links_description.text: For all policies relating to assessment and exams.

primary.introduction_text: If you do not achieve a pass result for your module, you may be offered a resit of your exam or resubmission of your end of module assessment (EMA) or end of module tutor marked assignment (emTMA). Not all modules offer a resit or resubmission opportunity.

rich_text_content.text: To find out whether your module includes this opportunity and the criteria you must meet to be eligible, check your assessment strategy (via the Assessment section on StudentHome).
Entitled to resit or resubmit
If you're offered a resit or a resubmission, it means you can just resit the exam or resubmit your EMA/emTMA without redoing the module. This only applies if your module result says:
'Fail: Entitled to Resit' then you're eligible to resit your exam.
'Fail: Entitled to Resubmit' then you're eligible to resubmit your EMA/emTMA.
We'll let you know the date and time for your exam resit as soon as we know it, and you can also see when the resit is likely to be on the Exam schedules page.
Timescales for resubmitting your EMA/emTMA should be available on your module website and we'll confirm the cut-off date separately either by email or on StudentHome.
Support available

There’s support available to help you with your resit or resubmission, although each module will have slightly different arrangements in place. Your Student Support Team (SST) may be able to arrange up to one hour of individual tutor support for you, but not necessarily with your most recent tutor. This will probably consist of an initial phone call or email from the tutor to discuss revision strategies, followed by a phone call or email support nearer to the exam/submission date.

Support could be either on a one-to-one basis or in a group, depending on the circumstances. You might also have access to an online forum, recorded tutorials and/or helpful resources on your module website. You should speak to an adviser from your SST  if you want to find out what’s available for your module.

In most cases, your module website will still be available and you'll be able to access materials and previous conversation threads in the forums, but it will be read-only and you won't be able to start any new discussions. If your module website is no longer available, you’ll be provided with resources to help you prepare.
Whenever you're approaching an exam or need to submit an EMA/emTMA, you should always familiarise yourself with contents of the Remote Exams Handbook or the EMA and emTMA guidelines booklet.
Financial implications of a resit or a resubmission
If you’re studying and you’re offered another opportunity to try to pass, you’ll automatically be registered for the resit or resubmission, and won’t have to pay a fee.
Resit and resubmission results
Module results for resits and resubmissions are normally capped. This means that if you're successful in your resit or resubmission you'll only be awarded the lowest available pass grade.

In some cases, the Module Result Panel (MRP) for your module can decide to award a non-capped resit or resubmission, if you sent us information about your special circumstances at the time you first took the exam or submitted the EMA/emTMA. Where this is the case, it will be noted on your resit or resubmission result. See Special circumstances – exams and EMAs for more details.

You can’t tell us about special circumstances after you've received your module result and the MRP can’t award you a non-capped result on the basis of special circumstances information submitted at the time of the resit or resubmission.
Postponing your resit or resubmission

If you’ve been offered a resit or resubmission within 12–16 weeks of your original exam or EMA/emTMA submission date but you’re not ready to do it straight away, you may be able to postpone to the next opportunity for your module. This could be as much as nine months away, but the resit or resubmission must be taken within 13 months of your first scheduled exam or submission opportunity. If your module allows this, there will be information on your module results notification page on StudentHome.
Not entitled to resit or resubmit

If your module result says 'Fail: No Resit/No Resubmission' then you're not eligible to resit your exam or resubmit your EMA/emTMA. To gain credit for the module, you'll need to retake the whole module to get a pass. You might be eligible for a reduced fee, so contact your student support team (SST) to arrange this. Don't register online or you'll pay the full fee. You can find out more at Failing a module and not entitled to a resit or resubmit.
Not happy with your grade?

Once you've passed a module you can’t retake it to improve your grade. However, it may be possible to decide not to count that module towards your qualification. This depends on your qualification pathway and your funding arrangements. Your SST can advise you and confirm if this applies to your module.
