rich_text_content.text: If you'll be studying on a low income or face unexpected financial difficulties, you may be eligible to apply for help with study related costs, including computer costs. Help is available through the Funding for study related costs scheme in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and Discretionary funding for students in Scotland.
For more information on the fund relevant to your nation see Funding for computers, internet, childcare etc.
Software and discounts

As a registered student, The Open University (OU) gives you free access to Microsoft 365 for the duration of your studies and for up to two years after. Included in the package are applications such as Word, Excel, Outlook mail and 1TB of online storage with OneDrive. Full details can be found in Microsoft 365.

Many retailers offer educational discounts to students when buying computers and computing equipment, including discounts on software and anti-virus protection. Be careful to compare the total costs when warranties or other options are all included. Extra equipment you might need include a headset with built-in microphone and a webcam.

Buying a computer is still a big investment. Rather than buy brand new you might get a better deal that still meets your needs by buying a professionally refurbished Grade A PC computer, laptop or tablet. If you buy a refurbished computer make sure it’s from a reputable company and it comes with a warranty.
When it comes to software, you could use compatible, free open-source software. The pros and cons of the different options are discussed in the The Computing Guide.

node.title: Sarah de Vos, Trainee on the NHS Science Training Programme
node.description: A former OU Student explains how she achieved a place on the NHS Science Training Programme
node.keywords: science, nhs science training programme
node.notes: Student and apprentice audience only. Do not make public. This was trainee's request.

rich_text_content.text: Listen to this series of audio clips from a former OU student on how she achieved a place on the NHS Science Training Programme.

fields.audio_title: Part 1 - Sarah talks about gaining a first class degree and describes the NHS Science Training Programme

audio_transcript.text:
Interviewer:
Sarah can you tell us what programme you’ve just managed to get a place on?

Sarah:
The NHS STP which is the Scientist Training Programme There’s a Recruitment Round every year in January. And the specialty that I’ve managed to get a place on is Medical Physics. But there are quite a few different specialties as well. They’re all a three year training programme which also includes a part-time Masters.

And at the end of that, you don’t have a guaranteed job at the end of that, but then you can apply for jobs with the NHS and you’ve got a pretty good chance of getting one because they pay you to train and they also fund the Masters. They wouldn’t do it if there weren’t any jobs at the end of it.

Interviewer:
Fabulous. And you studied with the Open University. Tell me a bit about what degree you studied.

Sarah:
OK. I studied a Physics degree, so it was pure physics. It’s one of the old degrees which was withdrawn at the end of last year but I’ve had a look and I can see that there’s some similar degrees. The actual science where you can follow a physics route.

And I did mainly Physics modules but also quite a few Maths modules. I specialised, so to say, in the Quantum side of things and also my project was on quantum. At the time I was still thinking that I might be going in to a PhD with it, so that was one of the options.

Interviewer:
It took five years to complete your degree.

Sarah:
Five years..

Interviewer:
Why did you decide to study with the Open University originally?

Sarah:
Because I was coming up to 30 and I’d been unhappy with what I was doing as a job for a little while but actually probably ten years. And I had this feeling it’s now or never if I want to make a change. I had that feeling initially just in my personal life, I need to make that but since I have met people of all ages who have been studying with the Open University which has been fantastic really to meet all these people who are making changes. But at the time for me I just felt I needed to make a decision. Because I just did not enjoy my job.

I was an environmental planner because I studied Landscape Architecture at uni originally. But it just wasn’t me and I knew and had known for years that I wanted to study Maths and Physics. I couldn’t take time out to go to uni because I couldn’t afford to study full-time. And when I found out about the Open University I thought, well this is ideal, I can combine work and study and hopefully that way, OK it would take me a little bit longer but at least that way I could start making some changes. And I figured time is going to pass anyway I might as well do it studying rather than looking back thinking I should have started.

Interviewer:
Did you work alongside all the way through your degree?

Sarah:
Apart from a few months yes. I think I just took a few months out at one point to concentrate on some exams and I was getting married at the time as well. So I just needed a little bit of headspace. I couldn’t do everything at the same time anymore. I probably would have managed it but I think sometimes you might ... I was doing quite a lot at the time. But yeah, pretty much all the way through, studied and worked and still managed to keep some friends as well.

Interviewer:
That’s brilliant. That’s brilliant. And we’ve talked a little bit about this but perhaps you could just tell us again in terms of this application for the STP programme. Did you have to at any point explain the content of your degree and how it mapped against their requirements?

Sarah:
I didn’t because the requirement for the specialism I went for the Medial Physics was you needed a Physics degree. So my degree was a Physics degree. You needed to have either a 2:1 or First. I had a First. I ticked those boxes so I think they never at any point felt the need to ask me anymore.

Interviewer:
And in terms of work experience what do you think was the most valuable work experience you brought to your application?

Sarah
Because I’m a bit older I’ve got sort of varied work experience. I’ve worked at a few different companies and I pulled bits of all those jobs together to answer any questions they had, whether that was interview or the application questions. I think just my experience in general, not having come straight out of uni helped me quite a lot.

Interviewer:
What kind of skills and experience were they looking for in general?

Sarah:
Probably quite a lot of it was what pretty much most employers would look for in terms of, you know, working as part of a team, that’s a very big one. Being able to take initiatives, to be responsible. Those kind of general things.

I mean the thing is always when you apply for any job you look at the job description. You look at the person specification and you find ways to evidence that where they ask. And that can be from previous jobs. It can be from a voluntary experience. It’s quite generic I guess but I didn’t have any specific physics work experience. I have no experience of working in a lab or for a medical physics department or anything like that. I had to use different experience such as working with customers. And a lot of people will have a similar. It’s all about tailoring it really. That is the same for many job applications.
But specific physics experience, not really. I can’t really remember that being asked.

Interviewer:
So having a specific experience of working within a physics environment or working in a lab environment wasn’t so important as much as those kind of softer skills, the team working skills, communication skills.

Sarah:
Oh yes definitely, that is extremely important actually. Again, which most people would do when applying for a job you read what’s required and then you find some sort of way to answer the question and show that you’ve got that experience somewhere. Whether that’s job, voluntary, school, anything. So yeah, that’s very generic really.

Interviewer:
Brilliant, brilliant. What attracted you to the STP, the NHS STP programme?

Sarah:
Because I’d be able to use my physics skills, something I’ve always been so interested in. And the whole way through the degree I knew, I was so happy doing it even though I was always busy and I didn’t have much time for anything else. And you get stressed at times because of exams, etc. But I was so happy doing it because I knew it was me. I had such an interest in Physics and in Maths and now I’d be able to use that for the rest of my life. And I’d be able to use it to help people. So what’s not to like really.

fields.audio_title: Part 2 - How the Careers and Employability Services helped and more about the skills employers want.

audio_transcript.text:
Interviewer:
Did you get any careers advice at any step along the way?

Sarah:
I did in the early stages of my Open University degree, probably the first or the second year. I just wanted to know what I could do with my degree. I wasn’t really thinking too much ahead yet but I still wanted to explore my options. At that point I was also looking at potentially teaching, may be a PhD, the NHS I was also interested in. The fact that there’s so much competition with the NHS STP that did scare me a bit so I didn’t want to put all my eggs in one basket.

I knew I’d probably apply for it but I thought let’s explore the options which is still a good thing to do. There’s always more than one thing out there. But I think there are so many things you can do with a Physics degree. If I hadn’t got on that I know I would have got on something else eventually because employers do really appreciate when someone’s been to the OU and has worked at the same time quite often. They respect that and they know that that person will have drive, will be determined, will be able to work, to take initiative.

Initially I was a bit worried about an Open University degree and I think a lot of people are because you think you study part-time, you don’t need any A Levels or anything, how are my employers going to view this. But having studied with the OU for five years I have spoken to a lot of people, I think both employers and students, I’ve realised that I needn’t have been scared about that.
I remember just being so happy that I could have this careers advice and that I could have it. That it was free.

Sarah:
It was a little while ago but I do remember coming away with a lot of information, feeling that someone had really put their time in to trying to help me explore my options.. I’d say carry on offering it mainly because people do need careers advice even if they don’t think they do.

And quite often it’s good to start thinking about these things before you finish. Because you finish and then all of a sudden, what am I going to do next. It’s good to have a little bit of a plan lined up.

Interviewer:
Definitely, that’s good advice. So your main advice is for students to contact the Careers and Employability Services at an earlier point in their degree and start that thinking process?

Sarah:
Yeah, I would say so. I know it’s difficult because you’re so busy. You’ve got a hundred and one things going on at the same time but still you can just put an hour aside and have a think and may be make an appointment. There’s quite a lot of information online. The Open University’s Careers site has several links to other sites and it looks like a lot of .... but it’s worth putting in a little bit of time in. And also just start asking around whether that’s other OU students because at that point you probably will have a bit of a network. And just starting thinking about it earlier, exactly.

fields.audio_title: Part 3 - Sarah explains the application and interview process and how she prepared for it.

audio_transcript.text:
Interviewer:
Just a few questions now on the kind of application process. What was the application process like? You said it started in January.

Sarah:
It was lengthy, it was. So it started in January. The window opens early January, it stays open for a few weeks. The first step is you have to fill out an application form. I can’t really go in to the questions. But there’s nothing there to try to trip you up. There’s the usual stuff such as your education and any memberships you’ve got that might be relevant, all that kind of stuff. There’s some essay questions. They’re extremely important, spend time on that.

And then after you do that form you have to then do some online tests as well, numerical reasoning, logical tests, that kind of thing. You will know immediately whether or not you’ve passed those. If you pass them that basically means that they’re going to look at your application.

Then you wait. The waiting’s hard for you. I tried not to think about it. I did apply for other things whilst I was waiting. But I think I found out in, yeah, I found out in March. So it’s a few months wait. Then in March I found out I had an interview. I’m sure the timescales are slightly different every year but it’s just a rough idea.

And I had a month to prepare for my interview and as soon as I found out about my interview. They do provide some guidance online both for the application form and obviously read it, read it again. Make sure that you haven’t missed anything out. It’s all there. It’s still there on the National School of Healthcare Science website if you wanted to look for next year, the next Recruitment Round.

There’s quite a bit of information but you’ve got your job description, the person spec, all of that. There’s also interview guidance. It’s all there. I think quite a few people don’t read it because there is a forum on student room where you do have a lot of people asking questions that you think, well if you had read it. So, yeah, if you want it make sure you prepare.

And then I spent every evening and every weekend pretty much preparing for the interview. Because they do tell you. Because they don’t tell you what they’re going to ask of course but there are several different stations, each have a different theme. I will tell you that because that’s sort of common knowledge. But there is a General Science, there’s a Specialist Science depending on what specialism you’re applying for. And then you’ve also got, I think, Values and Behaviour and also Leadership.

So that’s enough information there to prepare. It’s a bit vague but I just trawl lots of websites with types of interview questions. I read up a lot about Medical Physics and anything I could really find. General Science is harder to prepare for. But, you know, you’ve just done an OU degree so you’ll probably remember some.

There’s quite a few different posts available usually but they want to find people who are worth the money they invest because they’re going to pay you. They don’t want you to give up halfway or at the end of it go and work for someone else. So that’s just to keep in mind if you work hard to prepare it’s going to come across and you just need to convince them at the interview that you want this really badly and you’ve prepared for it. And then you’re pretty much there I’d say.
Once you’re invited for interview, you know, you’ve got a pretty good chance of getting a position because they only invite three people per position.

So yeah, at that point you’ve got a pretty good shot. At the time of interview they haven’t got your application form in front of you so everyone starts off equally. I can’t remember them asking me anything specifically about my degree, where I studied. It’s almost you’re there at the interview, we’re going to ask you the questions and you obviously made it to interview.

I was going to say something else... Oh yes the one thing I also did do I missed the Open Days. The NHS or the National School of Healthcare Science who organise the Recruitment Round they do have Open Days. So keep an eye on their website. Sign up to the Open Days, they go fast. I actually missed it but I organised a visit to a Medical Physics Department myself. I was just calling people not with much hope because I know everyone’s really, really busy.

Well I emailed first, then I phoned, of chasing. I felt bad but I thought if only to show at the interview how interested I am, how keen I am. So I got through to someone who was very happy to show me round. And that visit helped so much.

Interviewer:
Brilliant.

Sarah:
Yes. Because you’re reading. You’re reading about, in my case, Medical Physics. And they don’t want you to be an expert because you’re going to be doing the Masters. But they want you to have a clue of what you’re actually going in to. So you need to know, have an idea of the different techniques they use. You can find all of that on the Internet which is what I did. I did a lot of Googling. But if hadn’t gone to visit that department I don’t think I would have had as good an idea. Because when you see the line outs and then the accelerators it’s a whole different thing to seeing them to being shown how they work than to see a picture. So that helped me, get a place. I don’t know if I would have got it actually without.

Interviewer:
Did that also help you kind of be sure that it was the right career for you?

Sarah:
Oh yes, yes. I think I already knew before because I’d spoken with a few people as well, they already worked for the NHS as Clinical Scientists. And just research. There’s a lot of information on the Prospects. The NHS site as well. It’s all there for you to find no matter what specialism. And if you read it all, if you put the time in no matter what university you’re from as long as you’ve got 2:1 or more you’ve got as good a chance as anyone else.

Interviewer:
That’s really good advice Sarah, that’s really good. What would you have liked to have known about beforehand if you could go back? And now you’ve been through the whole application process what would you have liked to have known beforehand that might have helped you?

Sarah:
I mean the questions would have helped a lot.

Probably not to be as nervous and as intimidating partly because I almost didn’t apply because I thought ... When you see information online one of the first things almost always is, is it’s very competitive and it’s scary. And you think, oh, you know, I’m not going to be good enough, let’s not apply. Well as it turned out obviously I didn’t have to worry about that and I did put a lot of work in. If you don’t try you’ll never know.

primary.introduction_text: Failing a module can be disappointing, but it's not uncommon at all. Many students fail a module at some point in their studies and still go on to complete their qualification successfully.

note_body.text: Failing a module may impact on your ability to continue with the apprenticeship. All the information on failing a module, including what to do as an apprentice can be found in getting a fail result.

primary.note_title: If you're studying as an apprentice

rich_text_content.text: If you’ve failed your exam or EMA/emTMA
As long as you sat your exam or submitted your EMA/emTMA, you’ll usually be offered a resit or resubmission.
There's no formal structure for providing tutor support for a resit or resubmission. Contact your student support team (SST) who may be able to offer some help.
If you’ve failed and aren't offered a resit/resubmission

Some modules offer a resit of the exam or resubmission of the EMA/emTMA. If you fail the module because you weren't eligible for a resit/resubmission, or if your module doesn't offer them, you'll need to retake the whole module to get a pass.
Retaking at a reduced fee

You may be eligible to retake the module at a reduced fee but you need to contact your SST to arrange this, letting them know that you are retaking it. Do not register online or you'll pay the full fee.
Please bear in mind you need to have submitted all your assignments during the module (TMAs, iCMAs etc.) and sat the exam or submitted the EMA/emTMA to qualify for the reduced fee.
Further study and your academic progress
Failing a module won’t stop you continuing to study with us and completing your qualification.

However, there is sometimes an order in which modules should be taken within a qualification so you may need to rethink your plans and we may have to cancel enrolments you have made for future modules. Your student support team can help you to understand and consider your options.

We want you to make good progress and make good use of any loan and financial support. Therefore, if you fail or withdraw (and don’t defer your study) from three successive presentations of a module we need to talk with you about your options and you may be prevented from registering on any further modules. You may also lose any eligibility for financial support. We'll warn you after two fails or withdrawals that you may have this problem and advise you further. For more information see implications of unsuccessful study and the Academic Progress Policy.
Financial implications
If you live in England or Wales and are paying with a Tuition Fee Loan
If you’re paying for your studies with a Tuition Fee Loan, you‘ll still be liable for this debt and the interest that accrues even if you don’t pass your module.
If you’re receiving financial support
If you’re receiving financial support, you must make sufficient academic progress each year to remain eligible for it. Contact our Student Fees team for further advice.

rich_text_content.text: Your tutor is expected to mark and return your electronic tutor-marked assignment (TMA) within ten working days of the cut-off date. Working days don't include weekends or National Public Holidays. It can take several days for your assignment score to appear on your module record. If you have concerns that your score isn’t showing, please contact your tutor in the first instance. If you don’t get a response from your tutor, you should contact your student support team (SST).

If you submitted your TMA on paper, your tutor will send it to the Assessment Processing Centre for processing and it will be returned to you within 24 hours of receipt, so you should expect to receive it back within three weeks of the cut-off date. Where you haven't received your marked assignment after more than three weeks have passed, you should contact your tutor in case they were delayed. If you don’t get a response from your tutor, you should contact your student support team (SST).
For modules with an end-of-module tutor-marked assignment (emTMA) you won't be able to collect it until after you get your module result.
Collecting your TMA online
If you submitted your TMA online you’ll receive an email telling you when it’s available to collect. You can only collect your marked TMA once the cut-off date has passed.

Follow the link in the email to StudentHome and click on the Online TMA/EMA service for your module. Here you should see your score for the TMA and a button to collect it, although please note this may take a few days to display.

When you click Collect you’ll be able to download your TMA and tutor feedback as a zip file which you’ll need to save to your computer or device. When you open the file you should find your marked TMA with your tutor’s comments, and a file called an Assessment summary or PT3 which contains detailed feedback.
If the cut-off date has passed, and you can see that your TMA has been returned but you are unable to collect it or see the comments, please refer to the Troubleshooting section below.

Occasionally, there may be an inconsistency between the individual scores on the PT3 and the overall total. This is automatically identified and corrected prior to posting the score on your StudentHome 'Your module records' page. The total shown on 'Your module records' is your final score.
Troubleshooting
Can’t collect your TMA?

If after clicking on the Collect button to download your TMA, nothing happens (i.e. the File Download window doesn’t come up), please follow the steps below to resolve this issue if you’re using a Windows PC.
Click on Tools > Internet Options.
Click on the Security tab.
Click on Trusted Sites (green tick).
Press the Sites button.
Untick the ‘Require server verification (https:) for all sites in this zone’ box.
In the 'Add this Web site to the zone' type *.open.ac.uk
Press the Add button, then press OK.
Click on the Custom Level button.
Scroll down until you see the Downloads heading.
Set the ‘automatic prompting for file downloads’ radio button to ‘enable’.
Set the ‘file download’ radio button to ‘enable’.
Press OK, and retry the collection process, the File Download window should now come up.
Can’t see the comments on your marked TMA?

You need to be using Microsoft Word, Word Viewer, or a recent version of OpenOffice to open the file, otherwise the comments may not be visible. You may also need to create a folder to download your TMA into if you’re using a Windows PC
Right-click on your desktop and select New > Folder and name your folder.
Download your TMA from the online TMA service again and choose the option to Save rather than Open.
Select the new folder as the download location.
Once the file has finished downloading you should see three files including your marked TMA. You should now be able to see the comments on this document.
You can contact the OU Computing Helpdesk for help with accessing TMA files.
Make copies of your returned assignments

You should keep your own copies of your TMAs and your electronic confirmation of submission until you've received your module result. Make sure you save your information using a reliable storage solution, such a hard-drive or the cloud. You may also want to keep a copy on removable media such as CD, DVD or memory stick for future reference.

You can only access your TMAs from previous modules until 90 days after your module finishes and after this point we're not able to retrieve documents for you. You should make sure you download, save and back-up copies of your TMAs while you're still studying your module.
Appealing against your score
If you’re not happy with your TMA score you can ask to have it remarked, but please bear in mind that scores can go down as well as up as a result. The main steps are:
Query your score with the person that marked your TMA (usually your tutor) within 14 days of the mark being available to you.
Your marker will respond with a decision within 10 working days.
If your marker has not responded within this time period or you’re still not satisfied, you have 28 days to raise an appeal.

On modules without an exam or end-of-module assessment (EMA), you can't query the score of your end-of-module tutor-marked assignment (emTMA) in the same way you can appeal a score for your TMAs. You can still ask us to check your module result but we can only do this on the grounds set out in Requesting a check of your module result. You can't ask us to check your result just because you're disappointed with the score or feedback you've been given for your emTMA. See Can I appeal against my result? for more information.
